ground_truth: She turns and faces the hallway, her sweetness dissolves in a flash, replaced by repulsion, and quickly she reverses herself, re-entering her apartment and closing the door behind her. Meanwhile, all his considerable talent and strength are focused on seducing a tiny dog into the elevator door he holds open, sniffing at a particular spot on the hall carpeting. Melvin lets the elevator door close and advances on the mutt, who ignores him; the dog lifts his leg just as Melvin lunges and picks him up with a decisive heft, causing dog urine to squirt on the hall wall. Sensing a kindred spirit, the dog starts to growl and bark, taking a snap at Melvin, but Melvin, much meaner and quicker, holds the dog's snout shut with his hand and reaches for the garbage chute door, stuffing the dog in the chute and letting go, just as another apartment door opens, emitting loud party sounds and Simon Nye, in his early 30s, bolts into the hall. Melvin is about to enter his apartment when he notices Simon at the far end of the hall, starts to walk back to his apartment door directly opposite Simon's, and sees his black friend. Then he notices the handyman, tongue in cheek, trying to suppress his amusement. Melvin barely reacts as we hear a loud knocking, and he bursts from his chair. As Simon hears Melvin through the door, he takes a step back, and Melvin throws open the door, looking demonic. Melvin walks back into the apartment, about to close the door when Simon has another burst of bravery, but Melvin enters his apartment and slams the door shut. Meanwhile, Frank smiles affectionately; Simon turns serious as Frank waits patiently and Melvin jerks his door back open. Frank immediately grabs Melvin by his shirt, jerking him forward, and Melvin is scared but appears impressed. On a crowded and dirty street, Melvin comes walking briskly, like an animal wanting to pass through danger without giving off the scent of mounting fear, placing his palms together and extending his arms to cut a path through people, pointedly avoiding stepping on cracks and keeping his eyes focused on the terrain. Elsewhere, Carol Connelly talks with another mother, a customer, about her son for the umpteenth time; the mother nods too sympathetically, but Carol interrupts, and they turn away as Melvin walks a few paces to the waitress station where waitresses Lisa and Carol are talking.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: She rotates and confronts the corridor, her amiability disintegrates in an instant, substituted by disgust, and promptly she reverses herself, re-entering her flat and shutting the portal behind her. Meanwhile, all his substantial skill and power are concentrated on enticing a diminutive canine into the lift portal he holds ajar, sniffing at a specific area on the passage rug. Melvin permits the lift portal to close and advances on the pooch, who disregards him; the canine elevates his limb just as Melvin lunges and picks him up with a conclusive heft, causing canine urine to squirt on the passage partition. Perceiving a kindred soul, the canine commences to growl and bark, taking a snap at Melvin, but Melvin, much nastier and quicker, holds the canine's snout shut with his hand and reaches for the refuse chute portal, stuffing the canine in the chute and letting go, just as another flat portal opens, emitting loud festivity noises and Simon Nye, in his early 30s, dashes into the passage. Melvin is about to enter his flat when he observes Simon at the far end of the passage, starts to stroll back to his flat portal directly opposite Simon's, and sees his ebony companion. Then he notices the repairman, tongue in cheek, attempting to suppress his laughter. Melvin barely reacts as we hear a loud knocking, and he bursts from his seat. As Simon hears Melvin through the portal, he takes a step back, and Melvin throws open the portal, looking diabolical. Melvin walks back into the flat, about to close the portal when Simon has another surge of courage, but Melvin enters his flat and slams the portal shut. Meanwhile, Frank beams affectionately; Simon turns solemn as Frank waits patiently and Melvin yanks his portal back open. Frank immediately seizes Melvin by his shirt, jerking him forward, and Melvin is frightened but appears impressed. On a congested and grimy street, Melvin comes striding briskly, like a creature wanting to pass through peril without giving off the scent of mounting dread, placing his palms together and extending his arms to cut a path through people, pointedly avoiding stepping on fissures and keeping his eyes focused on the landscape. Elsewhere, Carol Connelly converses with another mother, a client, about her child for the umpteenth occasion; the mother nods too sympathetically, but Carol interrupts, and they turn away as Melvin walks a few strides to the waitress station where waitresses Lisa and Carol are conversing.

Melvin lets the elevator door close, approaches the dog, and picks it up, causing it to urinate on the wall. They turn away as Melvin approaches the waitress station where Lisa and Carol are talking.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: She turns around and faces the hallway, and in an instant, her sweetness vanishes, replaced by a sudden wave of repulsion. Quickly, she reverses her direction, re-entering her apartment and firmly closing the door behind her. Meanwhile, all of his considerable talent and strength are concentrated on the task of enticing a tiny dog into the elevator, which he holds open, as the dog sniffs curiously at a particular spot on the hallway carpet. Melvin allows the elevator door to close and advances toward the little mutt, who pays him no attention; the dog lifts its leg just as Melvin lunges forward and picks it up with a decisive heft, causing a stream of dog urine to squirt onto the hallway wall. Sensing a kindred spirit, the dog begins to growl and bark, snapping at Melvin, but Melvin, who is much meaner and quicker, holds the dog's snout shut with his hand. He then reaches for the garbage chute door, stuffing the dog inside and letting go, just as another apartment door swings open, releasing loud party sounds and Simon Nye, a man in his early 30s, who bolts into the hallway. Melvin is about to enter his own apartment when he notices Simon at the far end of the hall. He starts to walk back to his apartment door, which is directly opposite Simon's, and sees his black friend. Then he notices the handyman, who has his tongue in his cheek, trying to suppress his amusement. Melvin barely reacts as we hear a loud knocking, and he bursts from his chair. As Simon hears Melvin through the door, he takes a step back, and Melvin throws open the door, looking demonic. Melvin walks back into the apartment, about to close the door when Simon has another burst of bravery, but Melvin enters his apartment and slams the door shut. Meanwhile, Frank smiles affectionately; Simon turns serious as Frank waits patiently, and Melvin jerks his door back open. Frank immediately grabs Melvin by his shirt, jerking him forward, and Melvin is scared but appears impressed. On a crowded and dirty street, Melvin comes walking briskly, like an animal wanting to pass through danger without giving off the scent of mounting fear, placing his palms together and extending his arms to cut a path through people, pointedly avoiding stepping on cracks and keeping his eyes focused on the terrain. Elsewhere, Carol Connelly is engaged in conversation with another mother, a customer, about her son for what seems like the umpteenth time; the mother nods too sympathetically, but Carol interrupts, and they both turn away as Melvin walks a few paces to the waitress station where waitresses Lisa and Carol are talking.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: She pivots around and directs her gaze down the hallway, and in the blink of an eye, the sweetness that once graced her features is replaced by an overwhelming wave of repulsion. Without delay, she swiftly reverses her direction, retreating back into the sanctuary of her apartment and closing the door behind her with a firm resolve. Meanwhile, all of his considerable talent and strength are fully concentrated on the challenging task of coaxing a tiny dog into the elevator, which he keeps propped open, while the dog sniffs with great curiosity at a particular spot on the hallway carpet. Melvin allows the elevator doors to slide shut and advances toward the little mutt, who remains uninterested in him; the dog lifts its leg just at the moment Melvin lunges forward, scooping it up with a decisive heft, resulting in a stream of dog urine spraying onto the hallway wall. Sensing a kindred spirit, the dog begins to growl and bark, snapping at Melvin, yet Melvin, who possesses a much meaner streak and quicker reflexes, firmly holds the dog's snout shut using his hand. He then reaches for the garbage chute door, stuffing the dog inside and letting go, just as another apartment door swings open, releasing a burst of loud party sounds and Simon Nye, a man in his early 30s, who bolts into the hallway. Melvin is on the verge of entering his own apartment when he notices Simon at the far end of the hall. He starts to make his way back to his apartment door, which is situated directly opposite Simon's, and notices his black friend. Then he observes the handyman, who has his tongue in his cheek, struggling to suppress his amusement. Melvin barely reacts as a loud knocking echoes, prompting him to burst from his chair. As Simon hears Melvin through the door, he instinctively takes a step back, and Melvin throws open the door, appearing almost demonic. Melvin strides back into the apartment, about to close the door when Simon musters another burst of bravery, but Melvin resolutely enters his apartment and slams the door shut with finality. Meanwhile, Frank smiles with a touch of affection; Simon adopts a serious demeanor as Frank waits patiently, and Melvin jerks his door back open. Frank immediately seizes Melvin by his shirt, jerking him forward, causing Melvin to feel a mixture of fear and a begrudging admiration. On a crowded and grimy street, Melvin walks briskly, much like an animal intent on passing through danger without emitting a scent of mounting fear, placing his palms together and extending his arms to carve a path through the throng of people, making a point to avoid stepping on cracks and keeping his eyes intently focused on the terrain ahead. Elsewhere, Carol Connelly is engaged in a conversation with another mother, who is also a customer, about her son for what seems like the umpteenth time; the mother nods with overly sympathetic gestures, but Carol interrupts, and they both turn away simultaneously as Melvin walks a few paces to the waitress station where waitresses Lisa and Carol are deep in conversation.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: She turns and faces the hallway, her sweetness dissolves in a flash, replaced by repulsion akin to the sudden shift in mood caused by a foul odor wafting from the trash chute, and quickly she reverses herself, re-entering her apartment and closing the door behind her. Meanwhile, all his considerable talent and strength, honed from years of dealing with unruly pets in the building, are focused on seducing a tiny dog into the elevator door he holds open, sniffing at a particular spot on the hall carpeting notorious for lingering smells. Melvin lets the elevator door close and advances on the mutt, who ignores him; the dog lifts his leg just as Melvin lunges, reminiscent of a gamekeeper catching a stray animal, and picks him up with a decisive heft, causing dog urine to squirt on the hall wall marked by previous mishaps. Sensing a kindred spirit despite the circumstances, the dog starts to growl and bark, taking a snap at Melvin, but Melvin, much meaner and quicker due to his irritable nature, holds the dog's snout shut with his hand and reaches for the garbage chute door, a place of many discarded items, stuffing the dog in the chute and letting go, just as another apartment door, the one renowned for frequent lively gatherings, opens, emitting loud party sounds and Simon Nye, in his early 30s known for his career in graphic design, bolts into the hall. Melvin is about to enter his apartment when he notices Simon at the far end of the hall, starts to walk back to his apartment door directly opposite Simon's in a building designed with mirror-image layouts, and sees his black friend, recognized in the community for his charming wit. Then he notices the handyman, a man of few words but many skills, tongue in cheek, trying to suppress his amusement. Melvin barely reacts as we hear a loud knocking, and he bursts from his chair as if suddenly awakened. As Simon hears Melvin through the door, he takes a step back, and Melvin throws open the door, looking demonic with eyes wide and unyielding. Melvin walks back into the apartment, about to close the door when Simon has another burst of bravery, his courage fueled by past confrontations, but Melvin enters his apartment and slams the door shut with a resounding echo. Meanwhile, Frank, known for his patient demeanor, smiles affectionately; Simon turns serious as Frank waits patiently and Melvin jerks his door back open. Frank immediately grabs Melvin by his shirt, jerking him forward, and Melvin is scared but appears impressed by Frank's unexpected assertiveness. On a crowded and dirty street noted for its bustling activity and litter, Melvin comes walking briskly, like an animal wanting to pass through danger without giving off the scent of mounting fear, placing his palms together and extending his arms to cut a path through people, pointedly avoiding stepping on cracks, an idiosyncrasy linked to superstition, and keeping his eyes focused on the terrain. Elsewhere, Carol Connelly talks with another mother, a customer familiar with Carol's daily narrative, about her son for the umpteenth time; the mother nods too sympathetically, but Carol interrupts, and they turn away as Melvin walks a few paces to the waitress station where waitresses Lisa and Carol, who have been working together for years, are talking.

On a crowded and dirty street Melvin comes walking briskly like an animal wanting to pass through danger without giving off the scent of mounting fear placing his palms together and extending his arms to cut a path through people pointedly avoiding stepping on cracks and keeping his eyes focused on the terrain. Elsewhere Carol Connelly talks with another mother a customer about her son for the umpteenth time. the mother nods too sympathetically but Carol interrupts and they turn away as Melvin walks a few paces to the waitress station where waitresses Lisa and Carol are talking.

test_cases.description: The cat turns and faces the hallway, the cat's sweetness dissolves in a flash, replaced by repulsion, and quickly the cat reverses itself, re-entering the cat's apartment and closing the door behind the cat. Sensing a kindred spirit, the dog starts to growl and bark, taking a snap at the rabbit, but the rabbit, much meaner and quicker, holds the dog's snout shut with the rabbit's hand and reaches for the garbage chute door, stuffing the dog in the chute and letting go, just as another apartment door opens, emitting loud party sounds and the turtle, in the turtle's early 30s, bolts into the hall. The rabbit walks back into the apartment, about to close the door when the turtle has another burst of bravery, but the rabbit enters the rabbit's apartment and slams the door shut. The kangaroo immediately grabs the rabbit by the rabbit's shirt, jerking the rabbit forward, and the rabbit is scared but appears impressed. test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: She twirls and glances at the hallway, her sweetness evaporates in a flash, replaced by disdain, and quickly she pivots herself, re-entering her apartment and bolting the door behind her. Meanwhile, all his considerable talent and strength are focused on enticing a tiny dog into the elevator door he holds ajar, inspecting a particular spot on the hall carpeting. Melvin lets the elevator door shut and advances on the mutt, who disregards him; the dog raises his leg just as Melvin pounces and grabs him with a decisive lift, causing dog urine to splash on the hall wall. Sensing a kindred spirit, the dog starts to whine and whimper, taking a swipe at Melvin, but Melvin, much meaner and quicker, holds the dog's ears shut with his hand and reaches for the garbage chute door, placing the dog in the chute and releasing just as another apartment door swings wide, emitting loud party sounds and Simon Nye, in his early 30s, darts into the hall. Melvin is about to enter his apartment when he notices Simon at the far end of the hall, starts to stroll back to his apartment door directly opposite Simon's, and sees his black friend. Then he notices the handyman, tongue in cheek, trying to restrain his amusement. Melvin barely reacts as we hear a loud knocking, and he springs from his chair. As Simon hears Melvin through the door, he takes a step forward, and Melvin flings open the door, looking furious. Melvin storms back into the apartment, about to close the door when Simon musters another burst of bravery, but Melvin enters his apartment and slaps the door shut. Meanwhile, Frank grins affectionately; Simon turns solemn as Frank waits patiently and Melvin jerks his door back open. Frank immediately seizes Melvin by his shirt, pulling him forward, and Melvin is anxious but appears intrigued. On a crowded and dirty street, Melvin comes strolling confidently, like an animal wanting to pass through chaos without giving off the scent of building unease, placing his palms together and extending his arms to forge a path through people, deliberately avoiding stepping on cracks and keeping his eyes fixed on the terrain. Elsewhere, Carol Connelly chats with another mother, a customer, about her son for the umpteenth time; the mother nods too understandingly, but Carol interjects, and they turn away as Melvin saunters a few paces to the waitress station where waitresses Lisa and Carol are conversing.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: She spins and faces the bookshelf, her serenity dissolves in a flicker, replaced by disdain, and swiftly she pivots herself, re-entering her igloo and closing the hatch behind her. Meanwhile, all his notable charisma and endurance are focused on enticing a small cat into the wardrobe flap he holds ajar, sniffing at a specific spot on the porch rug. Kevin lets the wardrobe flap close and advances on the critter, who disregards him; the cat raises its paw just as Kevin lunges and scoops him up with a firm grasp, causing cat milk to dribble on the porch post. Sensing a similar soul, the cat begins to hiss and scratch, taking a swipe at Kevin, but Kevin, much grimmer and swifter, holds the cat's tail tight with his hand and reaches for the mailbox hatch, stuffing the cat in the slot and releasing, just as another igloo hatch swings open, emitting loud theme park tunes and Brad Frost, in his early 30s, darts into the porch. Kevin is about to enter his igloo when he spots Brad at the far end of the porch, starts to stride back to his igloo hatch directly opposite Brad's, and sees his white comrade. Then he notices the gardener, tongue in cheek, trying to conceal his hilarity. Kevin barely reacts as we hear a loud clanging, and he jumps from his hammock. As Brad hears Kevin through the hatch, he steps aside, and Kevin flings open the hatch, looking monstrous. Kevin strides back into the igloo, about to shut the hatch when Brad has another surge of courage, but Kevin enters his igloo and bangs the hatch shut. Meanwhile, Alice grins sweetly; Brad turns grave as Alice waits quietly and Kevin yanks his hatch back open. Alice promptly grabs Kevin by his collar, pulling him forward, and Kevin is startled but seems intrigued. On a bustling and grimy avenue, Kevin comes striding confidently, like a creature wanting to traverse peril without emitting the aroma of rising dread, bringing his fists together and extending his arms to carve a route through people, intentionally sidestepping puddles and keeping his gaze fixed on the path. In another spot, Erica Banks chats with another father, a shopper, about his daughter for the umpteenth time; the father nods too empathetically, but Erica interrupts, and they turn away as Kevin walks a few strides to the hostess podium where hostesses Laura and Erica are conversing.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: He spins and faces the courtyard, his curiosity vanishes in a flash, replaced by irritation, and hurriedly he pivots himself, walking back into his office and closing the window behind him. Meanwhile, all her vast charisma and agility are focused on guiding a small cat into the stairwell she holds ajar, observing a specific mark on the garden path. Jessica allows the stairwell door to shut and hurries toward the feline, who dismisses her; the cat stretches its paw just as Jessica leaps and scoops it up with a swift lift, causing cat fur to scatter on the garden bench. Recognizing an adversary, the cat begins to hiss and screech, trying to swat at Jessica, but Jessica, much gentler and quicker, holds the cat's paw still with her hand and reaches for the pantry drawer, placing the cat in the drawer and stepping back, just as another office window opens, emitting loud music and Mark Hill, in his early 40s, rushes into the garden. Jessica is about to open her office when she notices Mark at the far side of the garden, begins to stroll to her office gate directly opposite Mark’s, and spots her blue colleague. Then she notices the janitor, biting his lip, trying to conceal his amusement. Jessica barely registers as we hear a loud thumping, and she jumps from her desk. As Mark hears Jessica through the window, he retreats, and Jessica flings open the window, appearing furious. Jessica steps back into the office, about to close the window when Mark has another surge of courage, but Jessica steps into her office and slams the window shut. Meanwhile, Grace grins warmly; Mark turns thoughtful as Grace waits eagerly and Jessica yanks her window back open. Grace promptly holds Jessica by her jacket, pulling her close, and Jessica is startled but seems intrigued. On a bustling and congested avenue, Jessica comes jogging swiftly, like a creature seeking to slip through chaos without raising suspicion of rising alarm, clasping her hands together and stretching her arms to pierce through crowds, intentionally avoiding treading on shadows and keeping her gaze fixed on the horizon. Elsewhere, Susan Martin discusses with another teacher, a customer, about her daughter for the umpteenth time; the teacher nods overly understandingly, but Susan cuts in, and they walk away as Jessica takes a few strides to the cashier counter where clerks Alan and Susan are chatting.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: She spins and faces the aquarium, her sweetness fades in a flicker, replaced by disgust, and swiftly she pivots, re-entering her kitchen and sliding the curtain behind her. Meanwhile, all his considerable talent and strength are focused on coaxing a tiny turtle into the mailbox he holds open, inspecting a particular spot on the floor mat. Melvin lets the mailbox hatch close and ambles toward the turtle, who disregards him; the turtle raises his leg just as Melvin dives and hoists him up with a decisive grip, causing turtle drool to splatter on the floor tiles. Sensing a kindred adversary, the turtle starts to hiss and snap, taking a nibble at Melvin, but Melvin, much slyer and quicker, holds the turtle's beak shut with his hand and reaches for the closet door, depositing the turtle in the closet and releasing him, just as another window slides open, emitting a loud music beat and Simon Nye, in his early 30s, darts into the room. Melvin is about to exit his kitchen when he notices Simon at the far end of the room, starts to glide back to his kitchen curtain directly opposite Simon's, and sees his black companion. Then he notices the assistant, tongue in cheek, trying to stifle his chuckle. Melvin barely reacts as we hear a loud rustling, and he springs from his stool. As Simon hears Melvin through the curtain, he takes a stride back, and Melvin pulls back the curtain, looking monstrous. Melvin strolls back into the kitchen, about to draw the curtain when Simon has another surge of courage, but Melvin steps into his kitchen and yanks the curtain shut. Meanwhile, Frank grins warmly; Simon turns somber as Frank waits eagerly and Melvin swings his curtain back open. Frank instantly seizes Melvin by his collar, tugging him forward, and Melvin is startled but seems impressed. On a bustling and grimy avenue, Melvin comes striding briskly, like an insect wanting to scuttle through peril without emitting the scent of rising anxiety, placing his hands together and stretching his arms to carve a way through people, deliberately avoiding stepping on pebbles and keeping his eyes attentive on the ground. Somewhere else, Carol Connelly chats with another teacher, a visitor, about her cat for the umpteenth time; the teacher nods too empathetically, but Carol interrupts, and they turn aside as Melvin paces a few steps to the kitchen counter where cooks Lisa and Carol are chatting.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: She flips and faces the stairwell, her calm shatters in a blink, replaced by anger, and quickly she shifts herself, re-entering her studio and locking the portal behind her. Meanwhile, all her considerable skill and cunning are centered on enticing a small parrot into the escalator gate she holds ajar, pecking at a specific mark on the stair tiling. Marvin lets the escalator gate shut and advances on the bird, who disregards him; the parrot flaps its wing just as Marvin darts and grabs it with a swift snatch, causing parrot seeds to scatter on the stair banister. Detecting a similar nature, the parrot begins to squawk and chirp, taking a peck at Marvin, but Marvin, much tougher and swifter, clamps the parrot's beak with his fingers and reaches for the laundry chute cover, cramming the parrot in the chute and releasing it, just as another studio entrance opens, emitting loud music sounds and Stanley Long, in his late 20s, races into the stairwell. Marvin is about to step into his studio when he notices Stanley at the far end of the stairwell, starts to amble back to his studio entrance directly facing Stanley's, and spots his blue companion. Then he observes the gardener, smirking silently, attempting to hold back his laughter. Marvin barely responds as we hear a loud pounding, and he leaps from his couch. As Stanley hears Marvin through the portal, he takes a stride backward, and Marvin flings open the portal, looking menacing. Marvin strides back into the studio, about to latch the entrance when Stanley has another surge of courage, but Marvin enters his studio and slams the entrance shut. Meanwhile, Fred grins tenderly; Stanley turns solemn as Fred stands quietly and Marvin yanks his entrance back open. Fred instantly seizes Marvin by his jacket, pulling him ahead, and Marvin is startled but seems intrigued. On a congested and grimy boulevard, Marvin strolls swiftly, like a panther wanting to glide through peril without projecting the scent of rising anxiety, placing his fingers together and stretching his arms to slice a trail through people, intentionally avoiding treading on stones and keeping his gaze fixed on the surface. Elsewhere, Wanda Cassidy discusses with another teacher, a shopper, about her daughter for the umpteenth time; the teacher nods overly empathetically, but Wanda cuts off, and they pivot away as Marvin ambles a few strides to the chef station where chefs Laura and Wanda are chatting.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: She turns towards the hallway, her sweetness replaced by repulsion, and retreats into her apartment. Meanwhile, Melvin attempts to coax a small dog into the elevator, but the dog urinates on the wall as Melvin picks it up. The dog growls and snaps at Melvin, who counters by holding its snout and stuffing it into the garbage chute just as Simon Nye rushes out of his apartment. Melvin notices Simon and a handyman suppressing laughter. Simon hears Melvin and steps back as Melvin bursts out, appearing demonic. After a tense moment, Simon regains bravery, but Melvin slams his door shut. Frank smiles affectionately; when Melvin reopens the door, Frank grabs him, and Melvin is both scared and impressed. On a crowded street, Melvin briskly walks, avoiding cracks and cutting through people. Meanwhile, Carol Connelly discusses her son with another mother but is interrupted and turns away as Melvin approaches the waitress station where Lisa and Carol talk.
